The Sample Space

  • A sample space is a set that contains all possible outcomes of some function
  • A sample space is typically written as Ω\OmegaΩ
  • The following is an example of a sample space of a coin toss:
Ω={H,T}\Omega = \text{\textbraceleft}{H,T}\text{\textbraceright}Ω={H,T}

σ\sigmaσ-Algebra

  • Essentially, a σ\sigmaσ-algebra is a collection of subsets from Ω\OmegaΩ that satisfies the following:

    • ℑℑℑ is an algebra
    • A1,A2,...∈ℑA_{1}, A_{2}, ... \in ℑA1​,A2​,...∈ℑ implies A1∪A2∪...∈ℑA_{1} \cup A_{2} \cup ... \in ℑA1​∪A2​∪...∈ℑ

  • In other words, a σ\sigmaσ-algebra on a set SSS is a collection ℑℑℑ of subsets of ℑℑℑ satisfying the following properties:

    1. ℑℑℑ contains the empty subset ∅\emptyset∅ and XXX
    2. ℑℑℑ is closed under complement

    3. ℑℑℑ is closed under countable unions

      • This means for all A1,A2,...,AkA_{1},A_{2},...,A_{k}A1​,A2​,...,Ak​ in ℑℑℑ, then A1∪A2∪...∪AkA_{1} \cup A_{2} \cup ... \cup A_{k}A1​∪A2​∪...∪Ak​ are within ℑℑℑ
      • This also means that A1∪A2∪...∪AkA_{1} \cup A_{2} \cup ... \cup A_{k}A1​∪A2​∪...∪Ak​ is a countable collection of elements
      • Specifically, k is some theoretically countable number
      • In other words, the sets within ℑℑℑ are countable, and the union of all of the countable sets in ℑℑℑ are also countable

Examples of Algebras

  • Let the following be true:

    • XXX is an infinite set
    • AAA is the collection of all subsets of XXX which are finite or have finite complement
  • In this scenario, AAA would be an algebra of sets, which is not a σ\sigmaσ-algebra

The Probability Measure Function

  • A probability measure function is a function that maps events to its corresponding probabilities
  • A probability measure function is denoted as PPP

Probability Space (Ω,ℑ,P)(\Omega, ℑ, P)(Ω,ℑ,P)

  • A probability space is constructed with a specific kind of experiment in mind
  • One proposes that each time a situation of that kind arises, the set of possible outcomes is the same and the probabilities are also the same

  • A probability space consists of the following:

    • A sample space Ω\OmegaΩ that is a set of all possible outcomes
    • A set of events ℑℑℑ that is a set of events, where each event is a set of any possible outcome
    • A function PPP that maps the events to probabilities
  • Once the probability space is established, it is assumed that nature makes its move and selects a single outcome ω\omegaω from the sample space Ω\OmegaΩ
  • All the events in ℑℑℑ that contain the selected outcome ω\omegaω (recall that each event is a subset of Ω\OmegaΩ) are said to have occurred
  • The selection performed by nature is done in such a way that if the experiment were to be repeated an infinite number of times, the relative frequencies of occurrence of each of the events would coincide with the probabilities prescribed by the function PPP
